title: ‘That’s the frustration of DRS’
text:
Australian great Matthew Hayden savages DRS after critical dismissal of David Warner Staff writers, FOX SPORTS March 7, 2017 7:24pm 
CONTROVERSY surrounds the Decision Review System wherever it is used. 
For the first time in an Australia-India Test series, DRS is in place and there has been no shortage of controversy in the first two Tests — with champion Australian opener Matthew Hayden left stunned at a decision which led to David Warner’s dismissal. 
Warner had been given out lbw playing a sweep to Indian spinner Ravi Ashwin early in Australia’s chase, but after a long deliberation opted to review. 
The replay came up as ‘umpire’s call’, indicating at least a sliver of the ball had hit Warner in line with the stumps — but to Hayden’s eye that was hard to see. 
“That’s very disappointing,”he said in commentary. “There’s no doubt it clearly hit him outside the line of off stump, playing a shot. 
“Which in the laws of the game means only one thing (not out). 
“And that’s the frustration of the review system.” 
Fellow commentator Ravi Shastri chimed in, noting it is the “frustration of the umpire’s call”. 
“It goes upstairs, the umpire sees it upstairs and it gets passed back down. Why go up in the first place?” Hayden added. Shaun Marsh LBW call should have been reviewed 1:23 
Cricket: Shaun Marsh LBW call should have been reviewed. March 7th 2017 /video/video.news.com.au/Sport/Cricket/Australian Internationals/ Shaun Marsh LBW call should have been reviewed 
Australia’s anger was compounded when Shaun Marsh was given out lbw shortly after, despite the ball hitting well outside off stump when not playing a shot. 
With one review burned by Warner, Marsh opted not to review and potentially leave Australia with no reviews for the remainder of Australia’s innings. 
But replays showed that the ball would’ve missed off stump quite comfortably.
